title: 106_hr4146
content: The "Help Emergency Responders Operate Act" authorizes $10,000,000 for the Volunteer Fire Assistance Program for fiscal years 2001 and 2002. Additionally, it introduces loan guarantees for low-interest loans for volunteer fire and rescue services. The Director can guarantee loans to volunteer fire and rescue agencies for equipment, facility improvements, public education programs, and fire code enforcement using funds from the account established. The Director can guarantee loans for prevention, life safety, arson enforcement, training programs, and safety programs for firefighters and rescue personnel. The loan terms include a maximum term of 20 years, an interest rate 2 percentage points below prevailing rates, a principal obligation not exceeding $200,000, and appropriate security requirements for repayment. The Director may guarantee loans for various purposes with specific terms, including a maximum 20-year term, interest rate 2 points below prevailing rates, a principal not exceeding $200,000, and security requirements. Loans must have terms for complete amortization, periodic payments within borrower's capacity, and other specified terms. A 1% guarantee fee may be collected at loan issuance, and assumption of property acquired with loan proceeds is prohibited. The Director establishes criteria for selecting loan guarantee applicants, aiming to assist as many qualified applicants as possible within set limits. Loan recipients are not relieved of liability for loans acquired with guarantee proceeds. The Director may take necessary actions for guarantee payment and protection of US interests. Definitions include 'facility' as a building for fire and rescue services, excluding administrative support. The text discusses the establishment of a volunteer fire and rescue agency, which includes various emergency services. It also mentions the creation of a loan account to provide loan guarantees for these services. The text authorizes appropriations of $35,000,000 for fiscal years 2001 and 2002 to cover costs of loan guarantees under this section. SEC. 4. COUNTERTERRORISM TRAINING. Authorization of $20,000,000 for fiscal years 2001 and 2002 to provide grants to local fire and rescue services for equipment, including radio equipment. SEC. 5. BURN GRANT PROGRAMS. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency will establish an office to administer grants for burn prevention, acute burn care research, and after-burn treatment and counseling on a competitive basis to safety organizations, hospitals serving as regional burn centers, and governmental and nongovernmental entities. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency will establish an office to administer grants for burn prevention, acute burn care research, and after-burn treatment and counseling. $10,000,000 is authorized for each of the fiscal years 2001 and 2002 for this purpose. SEC. 6. FIRE AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL GRANTS PROGRAM. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency will establish a grant program for fire and emergency medical services departments. Grants can be used for personal protective equipment, firefighting equipment, wellness programs, and professional development for fire code enforcement personnel. The grant program aims to promote professional development, integrate technology for records management, train firefighting personnel, enforce fire codes, fund fire prevention programs, and modify facilities for safety. Grant applications must demonstrate financial need and commitment. The grant program requires a commitment from non-Federal sources equal to the grant amount, a cost benefit analysis for public safety improvements, and reporting to the National Fire Incident Reporting System. Grant recipients will be audited to ensure funds are used as intended. $80,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2001 and 2002. SEC. 7. ALLOCATION OF ELECTROMAGNETIC SPECTRUM. The Commission shall allocate the electromagnetic spectrum for interoperability use by public safety services between 139 MHz and 140.5 MHz, and between 141.5 MHz and 143 MHz. SEC. 8. SATELLITE SYSTEM. SEC. 8. Authorization of $15,000,000 for system improvements and $4,000,000 for operation and maintenance for the Hazard Support System. Secretary of the Interior to report on best methods of disseminating data for real-time fire detection within 9 months. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 is amended to include provision of assistance to local fire fighting, emergency medical, or rescue units serving low-income communities for equipment, vehicles, and facilities. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 is amended to include assistance for fire fighting, emergency medical, or rescue services in low- and moderate-income areas.
